text:
Leicestershire house price rises to eight times the average salary By TomPegden   The most expensive Leicestershire district to buy a home is Harborough VIEW GALLERY Leicestershire house price rises to eight times the average salary   The most expensive Leicestershire district to buy a home is Harborough Picture postcard - but homes in Rutland aren't cheap Comments (0) 
House prices in Leicestershire are now eight times the average salary – while homes in rural Rutland cost 11 times the average annual wage. 
The cost of a typical Leicestershire home was almost £216,000 last year, according to a Home Truths 2016/17 report from the National Housing Federation. 
The most expensive Leicestershire district was Harborough, where an average house would set you back £268,000. 
The least expensive area was Oadby and Wigston at £193,000. 
The report said homes in Rutland – with its pretty villages and busy market towns of Oakham and Uppingham – changed hands last year at an average price of £283,000, suggesting you would need to earn £64,689 a year for a typical 80 per cent mortgage there. 
Homes in Leicester were more affordable, the report said, with the average price at £156,400 – or seven times the average salary. 
Typical monthly rent in Rutland, it said, was £837 compared to £516 in Leicester. 
The federation – which supports housing associations – said the housing crisis was making it increasingly unaffordable to rent or buy in the East Midlands. 
But there was some good news. 
Mortgage lender Nationwide said UK house prices were growing at their slowest for more than a year – suggesting a slowdown in property prices could be on the way. 
Annual growth edged down from 4.5 per cent in December to 4.3 per cent last month. 
Nationwide chief executive Robert Gardner said there were indications the housing market would soften as household spending tightened. 
He said: "The outlook for the housing market remains clouded, reflecting the uncertainty surrounding economic prospects more broadly. 
"On the one hand, there are grounds for optimism. The economy has remained far stronger than expected in the wake of the Brexit vote. 
"However, there are tentative signs that conditions may be about to soften. 
"The economy is likely to slow through 2017 as the squeeze on household budgets intensifies and heightened uncertainty weighs on business investment and hiring." Read more Brexit has added an 'extra layer of uncertainty to our world' says Nicky Morgan 
Emma Foody, spokeswoman for the National Housing Federation in the East Midlands, said: "The overall story in England since the economic crash in 2008 has been one of general recovery and success. 
"However, the housing market has seen a relentless rise in the gap between house prices and people's salaries, and the East Midlands is no exception. 
"Attaining a mortgage is increasingly unrealistic and private sector rents make saving up that bit more difficult. 
"As this year's Home Truths report shows, it is more important than ever for the sector to be able to deliver homes that are truly affordable." Read more 'Shocking' figures show number of people in Leicester travelling by bus has slumped in last 7 years 
Brendan Walsh is a property expert at law firm Shakespeare Martineau which has a big office in Colton Square, Leicester. 
He said while uncertainties such as Brexit could effect consumer confidence and house prices, underlying demand remained strong in Leicestershire, and while price increases might slow there would still be growth. 
He said: "This is proving to be the case in the high level of activity for home buyers during what was usually a slow January period, and housebuilders active to secure land to meet short term supply. 
"Despite Government attempts to increase supply in new builds such as the highly successful Help to Buy scheme, demand remains strong and construction has not been increased to the levels required."
